rev.diff:
Line 49: Line 49:
==Protests==
==Protests==
â
=== 29 January ===
+
===Timeline===
  +
====29 January====
On 29 January, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of [[Jeddah]] in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing eleven people.<ref name="Montreal">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Flood+sparks+rare+action/4189873/story.html|title=Flood sparks rare action|date=29 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]] |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref> Police stopped the demonstration about 15 minutes after it started. About 30 to 50 people were arrested.<ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained">{{cite news | title=Dozens detained in Saudi over flood protests | date=29 January 2011 | publisher=[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] (Qatar)/[[Thomson-Reuters]] | url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/middle-east/140720-dozens-detained-in-saudi-over-flood-protests.html |accessdate=31 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w9qUZeyR |archivedate=31 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> On the same day, an online campaign started on [[Facebook]], making demands that included calling for Saudi Arabia to become a constitutional monarchy, and for "an end to corruption, an even distribution of wealth, and a serious solution for unemployment".<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb" />
On 29 January, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of [[Jeddah]] in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing eleven people.<ref name="Montreal">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Flood+sparks+rare+action/4189873/story.html|title=Flood sparks rare action|date=29 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]] |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref> Police stopped the demonstration about 15 minutes after it started. About 30 to 50 people were arrested.<ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained">{{cite news | title=Dozens detained in Saudi over flood protests | date=29 January 2011 | publisher=[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] (Qatar)/[[Thomson-Reuters]] | url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/middle-east/140720-dozens-detained-in-saudi-over-flood-protests.html |accessdate=31 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w9qUZeyR |archivedate=31 January 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> On the same day, an online campaign started on [[Facebook]], making demands that included calling for Saudi Arabia to become a constitutional monarchy, and for "an end to corruption, an even distribution of wealth, and a serious solution for unemployment".<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb" />
â
=== 5 February ===
+
====5 February====
On 5 February, about 40 women wearing black clothes demonstrated in [[Riyadh]], calling for the release of prisoners held without trial.<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb">{{cite news | first1=Ulf | last1=Laessing |first2=Asma |last2=Alsharif | pages= | language =| title=Saudi women protest, web activists call for reform | date=5 February 2011 | publisher=[[Swiss Info]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Saudi_women_protest,_web_activists_call_for_reform.html?cid=29428092 |accessdate=16 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wYAoCCPC |archivedate=16 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
On 5 February, about 40 women wearing black clothes demonstrated in [[Riyadh]], calling for the release of prisoners held without trial.<ref name="swiss_Saudi_5Feb">{{cite news | first1=Ulf | last1=Laessing |first2=Asma |last2=Alsharif | pages= | language =| title=Saudi women protest, web activists call for reform | date=5 February 2011 | publisher=[[Swiss Info]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Saudi_women_protest,_web_activists_call_for_reform.html?cid=29428092 |accessdate=16 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wYAoCCPC |archivedate=16 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
â
=== 10 February ===
+
====10 February====
On 10 February, a [[Thomson Reuters]] report claimed that 10 intellectuals, [[human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights]] activists and lawyers came together to create the [[Umma Islamic Party]] â considered to be the first political party in Saudi Arabia since the 1990s â to demand the end of [[absolute monarchy]] in the country.<ref name="threuters_umma_created">{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing| pages= | language =| title=Pro-reform Saudi activists launch political party | date=10 February 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-saudi-opposition-idUSTRE71942L20110210?sp=true |accessdate=11 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wQOpuC8A |archivedate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> On 18 February, all ten founding members of the party were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release.<ref name="washpo_umma">{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021802641.html |title=Saudi authorites detain founders of new party |publisher=Washington Post |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5whAiOr55 |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
On 10 February, a [[Thomson Reuters]] report claimed that 10 intellectuals, [[human rights in Saudi Arabia|human rights]] activists and lawyers came together to create the [[Umma Islamic Party]] â considered to be the first political party in Saudi Arabia since the 1990s â to demand the end of [[absolute monarchy]] in the country.<ref name="threuters_umma_created">{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing| pages= | language =| title=Pro-reform Saudi activists launch political party | date=10 February 2011 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-saudi-opposition-idUSTRE71942L20110210?sp=true |accessdate=11 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wQOpuC8A |archivedate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> On 18 February, all ten founding members of the party were arrested and ordered to withdraw demands for political reform in exchange for their release.<ref name="washpo_umma">{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021802641.html |title=Saudi authorites detain founders of new party |publisher=Washington Post |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5whAiOr55 |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
â
=== 17 February ===
+
====17 February====
According to Reuters Africa, a small protest was held by Shia in the small town of [[Al-Awamiyah]], near [[Qatif]] in the Eastern Province<ref name="af.reuters.com">{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71J0NZ20110220?sp=true |title=Three Saudi Shi'ites released after rare protest |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-02-20 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref> to demand the release of three political prisoners held since protests in the town on March 19, 2009 protesting an arrest warrant against the town's Shia imam, Sheikh Nimr Bagir al Namr. The prisoners were identified as Ali Ahmad al Faraj, the sheikh's 16-year old nephew, and two others, Ali Salih Abdul Jabbar and Makki Al Abbas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hns-info.net/spip.php?article17955 |title=Des hommes et des adolescents chiites maintenus au secret par les autoritÃ©s saoudiennes |publisher=HNS-info |date= |accessdate=2011-04-03}}{{fr icon}}</ref> The three prisoners were released on February 20.<ref name="af.reuters.com"/>
According to Reuters Africa, a small protest was held by Shia in the small town of [[Al-Awamiyah]], near [[Qatif]] in the Eastern Province<ref name="af.reuters.com">{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71J0NZ20110220?sp=true |title=Three Saudi Shi'ites released after rare protest |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-02-20 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref> to demand the release of three political prisoners held since protests in the town on March 19, 2009 protesting an arrest warrant against the town's Shia imam, Sheikh Nimr Bagir al Namr. The prisoners were identified as Ali Ahmad al Faraj, the sheikh's 16-year old nephew, and two others, Ali Salih Abdul Jabbar and Makki Al Abbas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hns-info.net/spip.php?article17955 |title=Des hommes et des adolescents chiites maintenus au secret par les autoritÃ©s saoudiennes |publisher=HNS-info |date= |accessdate=2011-04-03}}{{fr icon}}</ref> The three prisoners were released on February 20.<ref name="af.reuters.com"/>
â
=== 24 February ===
+
====24 February====
A protest was held in [[Qatif]] by Shi'a Muslims to demand the release of additional political prisoners.
A protest was held in [[Qatif]] by Shi'a Muslims to demand the release of additional political prisoners.
<ref name="AhramPoliticalPrisoners">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/6478/World/Region/Saudi-Shiites-stage-another-protest-in-oil-provinc.aspx |title=Saudi Shi'ites stage another protest in oil province |publisher=Ahram Online |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref> Video posted to YouTube confirms the existence and location of the protest, showing the roundabout 350 meters south of Ohud Road on King Abdelaziz Road.<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hrLvW9kmBOM&feature=related YouTube â â«ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ ÙÙØ§ÙØ±Ø§Ø¬ Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø§ÙÙÙØ³ÙÙâ¬â]{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref>
<ref name="AhramPoliticalPrisoners">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/6478/World/Region/Saudi-Shiites-stage-another-protest-in-oil-provinc.aspx |title=Saudi Shi'ites stage another protest in oil province |publisher=Ahram Online |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref> Video posted to YouTube confirms the existence and location of the protest, showing the roundabout 350 meters south of Ohud Road on King Abdelaziz Road.<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hrLvW9kmBOM&feature=related YouTube â â«ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ ÙÙØ§ÙØ±Ø§Ø¬ Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ³Ø¬ÙØ§Ø¡ Ø§ÙÙÙØ³ÙÙâ¬â]{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref>
â
=== 25 February ===
+
====25 February====
A group called ''Jeddah Youth for Change'' called for a rally in [[Jeddah]] on 25 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166978.html |title=Saudi youths call for rally in Jeddah |publisher=PressTV |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref>
A group called ''Jeddah Youth for Change'' called for a rally in [[Jeddah]] on 25 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166978.html |title=Saudi youths call for rally in Jeddah |publisher=PressTV |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref>
â
===Late February===
+
====Late February====
Brian Whitaker of ''[[The Guardian]]'' interpreted<ref name="guardian_subtle">{{cite news | first=Brian | last=Whitaker | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia's subtle protests are serious | date=2011-03-01 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/01/saudi-arabia-protests-middle-east |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtJo0K7m |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> the creation of a website for people to publish complaints about government services, "shakra.com",<ref name="arabnews_shakwa">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Site lets public air grievances about services | date=2011-02-26 | publisher=[[Arab News]] | url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article287105.ece |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtOlF8F5 |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> the circulation of at least three [[internet|online]] petitions calling for political and legal reforms<ref name="guardian_subtle" /> and a call for reform that is "the result of meaningful interaction and dialogue among the different components of a society" by Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]]<ref name="binTalal_NYT">{{cite news | first= | last=Al-Waleed bin Talal | pages= |authorlink=Al-Waleed bin Talal| language =| title=A Saudi Prince's Plea for Reform | date=2011-02-24 | publisher=New York Times | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/25/opinion/25alsaud.html?_r=1 |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtPXILKF |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> as protest actions that "in a Saudi context [are] momentous".<ref name="guardian_subtle" />
Brian Whitaker of ''[[The Guardian]]'' interpreted<ref name="guardian_subtle">{{cite news | first=Brian | last=Whitaker | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia's subtle protests are serious | date=2011-03-01 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/01/saudi-arabia-protests-middle-east |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtJo0K7m |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> the creation of a website for people to publish complaints about government services, "shakra.com",<ref name="arabnews_shakwa">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Site lets public air grievances about services | date=2011-02-26 | publisher=[[Arab News]] | url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article287105.ece |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtOlF8F5 |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> the circulation of at least three [[internet|online]] petitions calling for political and legal reforms<ref name="guardian_subtle" /> and a call for reform that is "the result of meaningful interaction and dialogue among the different components of a society" by Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]]<ref name="binTalal_NYT">{{cite news | first= | last=Al-Waleed bin Talal | pages= |authorlink=Al-Waleed bin Talal| language =| title=A Saudi Prince's Plea for Reform | date=2011-02-24 | publisher=New York Times | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/25/opinion/25alsaud.html?_r=1 |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtPXILKF |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> as protest actions that "in a Saudi context [are] momentous".<ref name="guardian_subtle" />
â
===3â4 March===
+
====3â4 March====
About 100 people, mostly men, and one group of women, marched in [[Al-Awamiyah]] and [[Qatif]] in the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]], protesting against prisoners held without trial, calling out "Peaceful, peaceful".<ref name="PressTV_PreRage" /><ref name="ThReut_100prot3March">{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing |coauthors=Elizabeth Fullerton | pages= | language =| title=Shi'ites stage small protest in Saudi oil province | date=2011-03-03 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE72259V20110303?sp=true |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxYBeY1v |archivedate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In Qatif, 22 of the protestors were arrested.<ref name="PressTV_PreRage" /> Police responses in Qatif included attacks on women protestors.<ref name="Qatif_women">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Massive protests loom in Saudi Arabia | date=2011-03-05 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/168262.html |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxlexNuX |archivedate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
About 100 people, mostly men, and one group of women, marched in [[Al-Awamiyah]] and [[Qatif]] in the [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]], protesting against prisoners held without trial, calling out "Peaceful, peaceful".<ref name="PressTV_PreRage" /><ref name="ThReut_100prot3March">{{cite news | first=Ulf | last=Laessing |coauthors=Elizabeth Fullerton | pages= | language =| title=Shi'ites stage small protest in Saudi oil province | date=2011-03-03 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE72259V20110303?sp=true |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxYBeY1v |archivedate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In Qatif, 22 of the protestors were arrested.<ref name="PressTV_PreRage" /> Police responses in Qatif included attacks on women protestors.<ref name="Qatif_women">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Massive protests loom in Saudi Arabia | date=2011-03-05 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/168262.html |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxlexNuX |archivedate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Protests following Friday 4 March prayers took place in [[Riyadh]] and [[Hofuf]].<ref name="PressTV_PreRage">{{cite news | first=DB/HRF | last= | pages= | language =| title=Anti-govt. protests hit S Arabia cities | date=2011-03-05 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/168261.html |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxZ3aAm7 |archivedate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In Riyadh, at least 3 people were arrested after criticising the monarchy.<ref name="PressTV_PreRage" /> Both alarmed and annoyed by such action, the Saudi government reminded citizens that public protesting was banned, and that the ban would be strictly enforced.<ref name="LAtimes_4March">{{cite news|last=Banerjee |first=Neela |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-saudi-protest-20110306,0,3128624.story?track=rss |title=Saudi Arabia protests: Saudi Arabia warns it will enforce ban on protests |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref>
Protests following Friday 4 March prayers took place in [[Riyadh]] and [[Hofuf]].<ref name="PressTV_PreRage">{{cite news | first=DB/HRF | last= | pages= | language =| title=Anti-govt. protests hit S Arabia cities | date=2011-03-05 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/168261.html |accessdate=2011-03-03 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wxZ3aAm7 |archivedate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In Riyadh, at least 3 people were arrested after criticising the monarchy.<ref name="PressTV_PreRage" /> Both alarmed and annoyed by such action, the Saudi government reminded citizens that public protesting was banned, and that the ban would be strictly enforced.<ref name="LAtimes_4March">{{cite news|last=Banerjee |first=Neela |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-saudi-protest-20110306,0,3128624.story?track=rss |title=Saudi Arabia protests: Saudi Arabia warns it will enforce ban on protests |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref>
â
===9â10 March===
+
====9â10 March====
Protests took place in the evening of 9 March in Qatif. About 600â800 protestors were present at a similar protest on the evening of 10 March, calling for nine prisoners to be released.<ref name="AP_qatif09_10March">{{cite news | first=Sarah | last=el Deeb | pages= | language =| title=Saudi police open fire at protest | date=2011-03-10 | publisher=The Washington Post/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/10/AR2011031003269.html |accessdate=2011-03-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5UDstQp |archivedate=2011-03-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="Guard_qatif09_10March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi expectations high before Friday's 'day of rage' protests | date=2011-03-10 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/10/saudi-expectations-high-day-rage |accessdate=2011-03-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5TA9Dd0 |archivedate=2011-03-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref> About 200 police were present. The police used "percussion bombs"<ref name="AP_qatif09_10March" /> and shot at protestors with gunfire for about 10 minutes.<ref name="AFP_Qatif10March_3injured"/> Three protestors were injured and hospitalised with "moderate" injuries.<ref name="AFP_Qatif10March_3injured">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi police wound 3 Shiite protesters: witness | date=2011-03-10 | publisher=[[France 24]]/[[Agence France Presse|AFP]] | url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110310-saudi-police-wound-3-shiite-protesters-witness |accessdate=2011-03-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5VXfe7K |archivedate=2011-03-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Protests took place in the evening of 9 March in Qatif. About 600â800 protestors were present at a similar protest on the evening of 10 March, calling for nine prisoners to be released.<ref name="AP_qatif09_10March">{{cite news | first=Sarah | last=el Deeb | pages= | language =| title=Saudi police open fire at protest | date=2011-03-10 | publisher=The Washington Post/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/10/AR2011031003269.html |accessdate=2011-03-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5UDstQp |archivedate=2011-03-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="Guard_qatif09_10March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi expectations high before Friday's 'day of rage' protests | date=2011-03-10 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/10/saudi-expectations-high-day-rage |accessdate=2011-03-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5TA9Dd0 |archivedate=2011-03-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref> About 200 police were present. The police used "percussion bombs"<ref name="AP_qatif09_10March" /> and shot at protestors with gunfire for about 10 minutes.<ref name="AFP_Qatif10March_3injured"/> Three protestors were injured and hospitalised with "moderate" injuries.<ref name="AFP_Qatif10March_3injured">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi police wound 3 Shiite protesters: witness | date=2011-03-10 | publisher=[[France 24]]/[[Agence France Presse|AFP]] | url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110310-saudi-police-wound-3-shiite-protesters-witness |accessdate=2011-03-10 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x5VXfe7K |archivedate=2011-03-10 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
â
=== 11 March â "Day of Rage" ===
+
====11 March â "Day of Rage"====
A "Day of Rage" was planned by Saudi Arabians on 11 March<ref name="saudirage11March">{{cite news | first= Richard |last=Spencer |coauthors= James Kirkup, Nabila Ramdani | pages= | language =| title=Libya: Muammar Gaddafi's regime on the brink of collapse | date=21 February 2011 | publisher=The Daily Telegraph | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8339435/Libya-Muammar-Gaddafis-regime-on-the-brink-of-collapse.html |accessdate=22 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wh6l0B7O |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> at noon in solidarity with protests in Libya and Bahrain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166931.html |title=Saudis plan pro-democracy rally |publisher=PressTV |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref> A ''[[Facebook]]'' page called for a "March 11 Revolution of Longing" and included demands for "the ousting of the regime" and for the national leader and the [[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia]] to be chosen by election.<ref name="torontostar_rev_longing">{{cite news | first=Ammar | last=Awad | pages= | language =| title=Protests continue across the Arab world | date=23 February 2011 | publisher=[[Toronto Star]]/[[Thomson Reuters]]/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/943434--protests-continue-across-the-arab-world |accessdate=24 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wk3pvTMz |archivedate=24 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> It also called for elections for national leadership, more [[women's rights in Saudi Arabia|women's rights]] and for freeing [[Human rights in Saudi Arabia#Political freedoms|political prisoners]].<ref name="guardian_rage_womensrights">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Middle East unrest: Saudi and Bahraini kings offer concessions | date=23 February 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/23/middle-east-unrest-concessions |accessdate=24 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtU78Xzb |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> As of 5 March, one of the ''Facebook'' groups calling for the Day of Rage had about 26,000 members.<!-- 2 March: 17k, ref name="DPA_Abdul-Ahadwas" --><ref name="eudigest_26k_FB">{{cite news | first=Sara | last=E | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Facebook Administrator Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahadwas reportedly shot as Saudi Arabia bans protests ahead of its Day of Rage | date=2011-03-06 | publisher=EU-digest | url=http://eu-digest.blogspot.com/2011/03/faisal-ahmed-abdul-ahadwas-saudi.html |accessdate=2011-03-09 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x3J2Tg1Y |archivedate=2011-03-09 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
A "Day of Rage" was planned by Saudi Arabians on 11 March<ref name="saudirage11March">{{cite news | first= Richard |last=Spencer |coauthors= James Kirkup, Nabila Ramdani | pages= | language =| title=Libya: Muammar Gaddafi's regime on the brink of collapse | date=21 February 2011 | publisher=The Daily Telegraph | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8339435/Libya-Muammar-Gaddafis-regime-on-the-brink-of-collapse.html |accessdate=22 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wh6l0B7O |archivedate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> at noon in solidarity with protests in Libya and Bahrain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166931.html |title=Saudis plan pro-democracy rally |publisher=PressTV |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref> A ''[[Facebook]]'' page called for a "March 11 Revolution of Longing" and included demands for "the ousting of the regime" and for the national leader and the [[Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia]] to be chosen by election.<ref name="torontostar_rev_longing">{{cite news | first=Ammar | last=Awad | pages= | language =| title=Protests continue across the Arab world | date=23 February 2011 | publisher=[[Toronto Star]]/[[Thomson Reuters]]/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/943434--protests-continue-across-the-arab-world |accessdate=24 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wk3pvTMz |archivedate=24 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> It also called for elections for national leadership, more [[women's rights in Saudi Arabia|women's rights]] and for freeing [[Human rights in Saudi Arabia#Political freedoms|political prisoners]].<ref name="guardian_rage_womensrights">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Middle East unrest: Saudi and Bahraini kings offer concessions | date=23 February 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/23/middle-east-unrest-concessions |accessdate=24 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtU78Xzb |archivedate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> As of 5 March, one of the ''Facebook'' groups calling for the Day of Rage had about 26,000 members.<!-- 2 March: 17k, ref name="DPA_Abdul-Ahadwas" --><ref name="eudigest_26k_FB">{{cite news | first=Sara | last=E | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Facebook Administrator Faisal Ahmed Abdul-Ahadwas reportedly shot as Saudi Arabia bans protests ahead of its Day of Rage | date=2011-03-06 | publisher=EU-digest | url=http://eu-digest.blogspot.com/2011/03/faisal-ahmed-abdul-ahadwas-saudi.html |accessdate=2011-03-09 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x3J2Tg1Y |archivedate=2011-03-09 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
On 11 March itself, protests continued for the third day in a row in Qatif and extended to Hofuf and al-Amawiyah, with several hundred protestors participating in the three protests.<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia 'day of rage' protest fizzles | date=2011-03-11 | publisher= | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-saudi-unrest-20110312,0,72557.story |accessdate=2011-03-11 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x76tP4d2 |archivedate=2011-03-11 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In Riyadh, the police presence was "overwhelming" by early in the morning, with large numbers of police cars present and helicopters that "crisscrossed the skies all day".<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3" /> There was also heavy military and police patrolling in Jeddah.<ref name="AFP_massiveshow11March">{{cite news | first=Omar | last=Hasan | pages= | language =| title=Massive Saudi show of force silences dissent | date=2011-03-12 | publisher=[[The Age]]/[[Agence France Presse|AFP]] | url=http://news.theage.com.au/breaking-news-world/massive-saudi-show-of-force-silences-dissent-20110312-1brok.html |accessdate=2011-03-11 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x75hcl2M |archivedate=2011-03-11 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Protests were not seen in Riyadh and Jeddah.<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3" /><ref name="AFP_massiveshow11March" />
On 11 March itself, protests continued for the third day in a row in Qatif and extended to Hofuf and al-Amawiyah, with several hundred protestors participating in the three protests.<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia 'day of rage' protest fizzles | date=2011-03-11 | publisher= | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-saudi-unrest-20110312,0,72557.story |accessdate=2011-03-11 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x76tP4d2 |archivedate=2011-03-11 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In Riyadh, the police presence was "overwhelming" by early in the morning, with large numbers of police cars present and helicopters that "crisscrossed the skies all day".<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3" /> There was also heavy military and police patrolling in Jeddah.<ref name="AFP_massiveshow11March">{{cite news | first=Omar | last=Hasan | pages= | language =| title=Massive Saudi show of force silences dissent | date=2011-03-12 | publisher=[[The Age]]/[[Agence France Presse|AFP]] | url=http://news.theage.com.au/breaking-news-world/massive-saudi-show-of-force-silences-dissent-20110312-1brok.html |accessdate=2011-03-11 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5x75hcl2M |archivedate=2011-03-11 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Protests were not seen in Riyadh and Jeddah.<ref name="LATimes_QatifDay3" /><ref name="AFP_massiveshow11March" />
â
===13 March===
+
====13 March====
More than 200 people protested outside of the [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Ministry of the Interior]] in Riyadh on Sunday 13 March, asking for information about prisoners and their immediate release.<ref name="KSA_AP_13March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudis protest outside Interior Ministry | date=2011-03-13 | publisher=[[The News Tribune]]/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/2011/03/13/1582849/saudis-organize-outside-interior.html |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xG836rzV |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="KSA_Guardian_13March">{{cite news | first=Simon | last=Tisdall | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia polices the region as trouble stirs at home | date=2011-03-14 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/14/saudi-arabia-bahrain-iran-us |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xG83Z0lN |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Protestor Ahmed Ali said that his brother has been imprisoned for four years and nothing is known about him nor the charges against him. Another protestor said that his father has been in prison for 10 years without receiving medical attention for his colon cancer nor a trial.<ref name="KSA_AP_13March" /> The protestors asked to meet with the Minister for the Interior Prince [[Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud]]. The request was refused and entry to the Ministry building was refused.<ref name="KSA_AP_13March" />
More than 200 people protested outside of the [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Ministry of the Interior]] in Riyadh on Sunday 13 March, asking for information about prisoners and their immediate release.<ref name="KSA_AP_13March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudis protest outside Interior Ministry | date=2011-03-13 | publisher=[[The News Tribune]]/[[Associated Press|AP]] | url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/2011/03/13/1582849/saudis-organize-outside-interior.html |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xG836rzV |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="KSA_Guardian_13March">{{cite news | first=Simon | last=Tisdall | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia polices the region as trouble stirs at home | date=2011-03-14 | publisher=The Guardian | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/mar/14/saudi-arabia-bahrain-iran-us |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xG83Z0lN |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Protestor Ahmed Ali said that his brother has been imprisoned for four years and nothing is known about him nor the charges against him. Another protestor said that his father has been in prison for 10 years without receiving medical attention for his colon cancer nor a trial.<ref name="KSA_AP_13March" /> The protestors asked to meet with the Minister for the Interior Prince [[Nayef bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud]]. The request was refused and entry to the Ministry building was refused.<ref name="KSA_AP_13March" />
â
===15â18 March===
+
====15â18 March====
On 15 March, about 1000 people protested in Qatif calling for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from Bahrain, where it is being used against [[2011 Bahraini protests|Bahraini protestors]].<ref name="bloom_15March_1kQatif">{{cite news | first=Donna | last=Abu Nasr | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia Demonstrators Hold Rallies in al-Qatif, Awwamiya | date=2011-03-16 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-16/saudi-arabia-demonstrators-hold-rallies-in-al-qatif-awwamiya.html |accessdate=2011-03-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHj2ny3J |archivedate=2011-03-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> A related protest took place in al-Awamiyah.<ref name="bloom_15March_1kQatif" /> Hundreds of people protested in Qatif and the nearby region on 16 March, calling for the release of prisoners and expressing support for the [[2011 Bahraini protests|2011 Bahraini protestors]].<ref name="KSA_ThReut_16March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites protest, support Bahrain brethren | date=2011-03-16 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/us-bahrain-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72F8ZB20110316 |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xGAhIzV4 |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Anti-riot forces were present at the protests. The Qatif demonstration lasted for about half an hour. Protestors called for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from Bahrain.<ref name="KSA_ThReut_16March" /> The protests continued the following day, 17 March, in and near Qatif, with similar demands, and about 4000 protestors in Qatif.<ref name="pressTV_17March_4kQatif">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Several injured in Saudi Arabia protest | date=2011-03 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/170496.html |accessdate=2011-03-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHkV8dvZ |archivedate=2011-03-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Police fired rubber bullets and several people were injured.<ref name="pressTV_17March_4kQatif" /> One slogan used in the protests was "Bahrain Free Free. Saudi forces out!".<ref name="KSA_ThReut_17March">{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites call for Bahrain troop withdrawal | date=2011-03-17 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/17/us-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72G7JQ20110317 |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xGBKJvGP |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Similar protests took place on Friday 18 March, in [[Qatif]],<ref name="jpost_18March_5protests" /> [[Omran]], [[al-Awamiyah]] (about 2500 protestors), [[Safwa City]] and [[Qatif#Towns and villages|al-Rabeeya]] (1000 protestors each).<ref name="arabtimes_4kQatifetc_18March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Kuwait Navy set for Bahrain - Saudi Shias Rally | date=2011-03-18 | publisher=[[Arab Times]] | url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/166871/t/Kuwait-Navy-set-for-Bahrain/Default.aspx |accessdate=2011-03-19 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xIz3sxxL |archivedate=2011-03-19 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Ten people in Omran were injured from being hit by police batons.<ref name="arabtimes_4kQatifetc_18March" /> One of the slogans in Qatif was "One people not two people â the people of Qatif and Bahrain!"<ref name="jpost_18March_5protests">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Shi'ites protest peacefully in eastern Saudi Arabia | date=2011-03-18 | publisher=[[Jerusalem Post]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=212802 |accessdate=2011-03-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHk9zw1s |archivedate=2011-03-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
On 15 March, about 1000 people protested in Qatif calling for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from Bahrain, where it is being used against [[2011 Bahraini protests|Bahraini protestors]].<ref name="bloom_15March_1kQatif">{{cite news | first=Donna | last=Abu Nasr | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Arabia Demonstrators Hold Rallies in al-Qatif, Awwamiya | date=2011-03-16 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-16/saudi-arabia-demonstrators-hold-rallies-in-al-qatif-awwamiya.html |accessdate=2011-03-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHj2ny3J |archivedate=2011-03-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> A related protest took place in al-Awamiyah.<ref name="bloom_15March_1kQatif" /> Hundreds of people protested in Qatif and the nearby region on 16 March, calling for the release of prisoners and expressing support for the [[2011 Bahraini protests|2011 Bahraini protestors]].<ref name="KSA_ThReut_16March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites protest, support Bahrain brethren | date=2011-03-16 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/us-bahrain-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72F8ZB20110316 |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xGAhIzV4 |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Anti-riot forces were present at the protests. The Qatif demonstration lasted for about half an hour. Protestors called for the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] to be withdrawn from Bahrain.<ref name="KSA_ThReut_16March" /> The protests continued the following day, 17 March, in and near Qatif, with similar demands, and about 4000 protestors in Qatif.<ref name="pressTV_17March_4kQatif">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Several injured in Saudi Arabia protest | date=2011-03 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/170496.html |accessdate=2011-03-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHkV8dvZ |archivedate=2011-03-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Police fired rubber bullets and several people were injured.<ref name="pressTV_17March_4kQatif" /> One slogan used in the protests was "Bahrain Free Free. Saudi forces out!".<ref name="KSA_ThReut_17March">{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites call for Bahrain troop withdrawal | date=2011-03-17 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/17/us-saudi-protests-idUSTRE72G7JQ20110317 |accessdate=2011-03-17 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xGBKJvGP |archivedate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Similar protests took place on Friday 18 March, in [[Qatif]],<ref name="jpost_18March_5protests" /> [[Omran]], [[al-Awamiyah]] (about 2500 protestors), [[Safwa City]] and [[Qatif#Towns and villages|al-Rabeeya]] (1000 protestors each).<ref name="arabtimes_4kQatifetc_18March">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Kuwait Navy set for Bahrain - Saudi Shias Rally | date=2011-03-18 | publisher=[[Arab Times]] | url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/166871/t/Kuwait-Navy-set-for-Bahrain/Default.aspx |accessdate=2011-03-19 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xIz3sxxL |archivedate=2011-03-19 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Ten people in Omran were injured from being hit by police batons.<ref name="arabtimes_4kQatifetc_18March" /> One of the slogans in Qatif was "One people not two people â the people of Qatif and Bahrain!"<ref name="jpost_18March_5protests">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Shi'ites protest peacefully in eastern Saudi Arabia | date=2011-03-18 | publisher=[[Jerusalem Post]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=212802 |accessdate=2011-03-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xHk9zw1s |archivedate=2011-03-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
â
===20 Marchâ1 April===
+
====20 Marchâ1 April====
Calls for protests on 20 March were made on a Facebook page in late February.<ref name="ThReut_20MarchRage">{{cite news | first=Carolyn | last=Cohn |coauthor=Sebastian Tong | pages= | language =| title= Saudi, Bahraini debt insurance costs rise â Markit| date=2011-03-02 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/02/mideast-swaps-idUSLDE7210LL20110302 |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtTG0zyW |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Calls for protests on 20 March were made on a Facebook page in late February.<ref name="ThReut_20MarchRage">{{cite news | first=Carolyn | last=Cohn |coauthor=Sebastian Tong | pages= | language =| title= Saudi, Bahraini debt insurance costs rise â Markit| date=2011-03-02 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/02/mideast-swaps-idUSLDE7210LL20110302 |accessdate=2011-03-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wtTG0zyW |archivedate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Line 99: Line 99:
Similar protests by hundreds of people in villages near Qatif took place on Friday 25 March <ref name="ThReut_Qatif25Mar">{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham | pages= | language =| title=Hundreds of Saudi Shi'ites protest in east | date=2011-03-25 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE72O3RL20110325?sp=true |accessdate=2011-03-25 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xSLWasoJ |archivedate=2011-03-25 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and again in Qatif<ref name="PressTV_1April">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi demonstrators hold rally in Qatif | date=2011-04-01 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/172590.html |accessdate=2011-04-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeV9lhbt |archivedate=2011-04-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and al-Awamiyah<ref name="ThReut_1April">{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham |coauthors=Janet Lawrence | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites protest peacefully in east | date=2011-04-01 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE7304C920110401?sp=true |accessdate=2011-04-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeV902KM |archivedate=2011-04-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> on 1 April.
Similar protests by hundreds of people in villages near Qatif took place on Friday 25 March <ref name="ThReut_Qatif25Mar">{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham | pages= | language =| title=Hundreds of Saudi Shi'ites protest in east | date=2011-03-25 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE72O3RL20110325?sp=true |accessdate=2011-03-25 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xSLWasoJ |archivedate=2011-03-25 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and again in Qatif<ref name="PressTV_1April">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Saudi demonstrators hold rally in Qatif | date=2011-04-01 | publisher=[[Press TV]] | url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/172590.html |accessdate=2011-04-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeV9lhbt |archivedate=2011-04-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and al-Awamiyah<ref name="ThReut_1April">{{cite news | first=Jason | last=Benham |coauthors=Janet Lawrence | pages= | language =| title=Saudi Shi'ites protest peacefully in east | date=2011-04-01 | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE7304C920110401?sp=true |accessdate=2011-04-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xeV902KM |archivedate=2011-04-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> on 1 April.
â
===Early April teachers' and graduates' protests===
+
====Early April teachers' and graduates' protests====
â
About a hundred literacy campaign teachers held a street demonstration outside the [[Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia|Ministry of Civil Services]] in Riyadh on 5 April, demanding to be employed [[full-time]]. Similar demonstrations took place in [[Taâif]] and [[Tabuk, Saudi Arabia|Tabuk]]. Officials at the Ministry in Riyadh promised to fulfill the demands.<ref name="presstv_literacy_5April" /> On Sunday 10 April, small protests by literacy teachers and unemployed university graduates regarding [[labor rights]] took place in front of the Ministries of Civil Services and Education in Riyadh and the Ministry of Education in Jeddah.<ref name="ThReut_10April_univ" /><ref name="ArabNews_10April_univ" /> [[Facebook]] was used for coordinating one of the protests.<ref name="ArabNews_10April_univ" />
+
About a hundred literacy campaign teachers held a street demonstration outside the [[Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia|Ministry of Civil Services]] in Riyadh on 5 April, demanding to be employed [[full-time]]. Similar demonstrations took place in [[Taâif]] and [[Tabuk, Saudi Arabia|Tabuk]]. Officials at the Ministry in Riyadh promised to fulfill the demands.<ref name="presstv_literacy_5April" />
===8 April===
===8 April===
Hundreds of people again protested in Qatif and al-Awamiyah against the use of the Peninsula Shield Force troops from the six Gulf Cooperation Council states against the 2011 Bahraini uprising and for their own political rights and freedoms.<ref name="ThReut_Qatif8April" /><ref name="PressTV_Qatif8April" /> ''Thomson Reuters'' stated that no riot police were seen at the Qatif demonstration.<ref name="ThReut_Qatif8April" /> ''[[Press TV]]'' said that there was a heavy presence of security forces at both demonstrations, but no clashes or arrests occurred.<ref name="PressTV_Qatif8April" />
Hundreds of people again protested in Qatif and al-Awamiyah against the use of the Peninsula Shield Force troops from the six Gulf Cooperation Council states against the 2011 Bahraini uprising and for their own political rights and freedoms.<ref name="ThReut_Qatif8April" /><ref name="PressTV_Qatif8April" /> ''Thomson Reuters'' stated that no riot police were seen at the Qatif demonstration.<ref name="ThReut_Qatif8April" /> ''[[Press TV]]'' said that there was a heavy presence of security forces at both demonstrations, but no clashes or arrests occurred.<ref name="PressTV_Qatif8April" />
  +   +
====10 April===
  +
On Sunday 10 April, small protests by literacy teachers and unemployed university graduates regarding [[labor rights]] took place in front of the Ministries of Civil Services and Education in Riyadh and the Ministry of Education in Jeddah.<ref name="ThReut_10April_univ" /><ref name="ArabNews_10April_univ" /> [[Facebook]] was used for coordinating one of the protests.<ref name="ArabNews_10April_univ" />
==Response==
==Response==
